newsitem.title: UK: N. Sea crudes hold steady, ignore futures dip.
newsitem.headline: N. Sea crudes hold steady, ignore futures dip.

text.p: North Sea crude markets were holding steady on Monday afternoon, ignoring Iraqi crude sale-led volatility in IPE Brent futures amid good interest for December cargoes, traders said.
"The market was picked clean last week but there still some good buying interest," one trader said.
"There's good interest for Dec cargoes, I think people are looking to square up early for the Christmas holiday season," another added.
Dated Brent held steady around Dec Brent -35 cents with the Jan/Feb spread trading firmer at +58 cents.
The Dec/Jan intermonth spread held notionally steady around +70/72 cents.
Three Brent cargoes were nominated from the paper chains on Monday, including one cargo deferred from Friday.
A Gullfaks C loading Dec 12-14 traded on Monday at a stronger Dated Brent +34 cents and a Dec 13 loading Forties cargoe moved at a firm Dated Brent -27 cents to a French refiner.
Balance of first decade December Ekofisk cargoes are now thought cleared with the last cargo sold by a French major at dated Brent +9 cents for Dec 6 loading.
A second decade cargo was heared traded at Dated Brent +23 cents.
Mediterranean refiners were slow to come out to buy crude on Monday following the strong differentials seen traded on Urals on Friday.
Some refiners argued that with only traders buying Urals the levels were too high and would not give "any margin" in their refineries.
"Brent would be better for us than Urals. Brent gives 65 cents more than Urals. Sweet is definitely better than sour and refiners that I have spoken to seem relaxed," one refiner said.
